He earned a BSEE from Purdue University (1951) and began his career at GM's AC Electronics Division. He also chairs the Coalition of Professional and Scientific Associations supporting the National Earthquake Hazard Reduction Program.

He is the Mary and Robert Raymond Professor of Economics at Stanford University and a Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution. He served as Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs under President George W. Bush (2001-2005) and was senior policy advisor during the Bush 2000 presidential campaign. He was President of the Mont Pelerin Society from 2018 to 2020.

He was a national security adviser to President Reagan before resigning in 1983 following an insider trading investigation. In the 1970s, he co-founded Clos du Bois winery in Sonoma County, which was sold to Hiram Walker in 1988 for ~$40 million. He authored 'At the Abyss: An Insider's History of the Cold War' (2004) and 'The Nuclear Express' (2009). He had a lifelong connection to Sonoma County, California.

He resides in Orinda, CA and was honored as Man of the Year by the Bay Area Tumor Institute in 2005.

He is Co-Chairman of The Woodbridge Company (which controls 67.8% of Thomson Reuters) and a Director of Thomson Reuters since 1995. His net worth is estimated at $10.1 billion.

He toured with Stanley Clarke's band (2003-2010) and since 2021 has been a featured member of Bob Weir's Wolf Bros/Wolf Pack Band, performing at Red Rocks, The Greek Theatre, and Radio City Music Hall. He joined UCSF's Department of Orthopaedic Surgery as Chair in 2007, received the James L. Young endowed professorship in 2014, and the Pappas Endowed Chair in 2021. He is past President of the Knee Society and the American Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons.

name: Kissinger, Henry A.
title: Founder and Chairman, Kissinger Associates, Inc. (1982â€“2023); U.S. Secretary of State (1973â€“1977); National Security Advisor (1969â€“1975); Nobel Peace Prize laureate (1973). Deceased November 29, 2023.
donations: Predominantly Republican donor. FEC-reported (2006 cycle, $8,100): John McCain 2008 Exploratory ($2,100), Straight Talk America PAC ($5,000), Pat Roberts for Senate ($500). Historically aligned with Rockefeller/moderate Republican wing; endorsed and advised multiple Republican and Democratic administrations post-office. Kissinger Associates lobbying activity reported separately from personal donations.
ngos: Council on Foreign Relations (Director Emeritus; member since 1950s); Trilateral Commission (founding member, 1973); Bilderberg Group (Steering Committee, regular attendee since 1957); American Express (board director, 1984â€“2013); Freeport-McMoRan (board director, 1995â€“2015); CBS Corporation (board director, 2001â€“2018); Hollinger International (board director, 1995â€“2001); International Rescue Committee (advisory board); Aspen Institute (trustee); Metropolitan Museum of Art (trustee emeritus)
notes: One of the most influential and controversial U.S. foreign policy figures of the 20th century. National Security Advisor to Nixon (1969â€“1975) and Secretary of State under Nixon and Ford (1973â€“1977). Nobel Peace Prize 1973 (for Paris Peace Accords ending U.S. involvement in Vietnam; two North Vietnamese negotiators declined the prize in protest). Key architect of dÃ©tente with the Soviet Union and the historic opening to China (1972). Ordered or sanctioned: secret bombing of Cambodia (1969â€“1973, ~2.7M tons of bombs); covert destabilization of Chile leading to Pinochet coup (Sept. 11, 1973); support for Pakistan during Bangladesh genocide (1971); green-lighting Indonesian invasion of East Timor (1975). Authorized FBI wiretaps of his own NSC staff and journalists to find intelligence leaks. Founded Kissinger Associates (1982), an international geopolitical consulting firm; client list deliberately kept secret but has included major multinationals and foreign governments including China. Consulted informally by every U.S. president from Nixon through Biden. Appointed to chair the 9/11 Commission (2002) but resigned within weeks due to conflicts of interest from undisclosed consulting clients. Subject of Christopher Hitchens' 'The Trial of Henry Kissinger' (2001), arguing he is a war criminal liable for prosecution. Books include: 'A World Restored' (1957), 'Nuclear Weapons and Foreign Policy' (1957), 'The White House Years' (1979), 'Years of Upheaval' (1982), 'Diplomacy' (1994), 'Does America Need a Foreign Policy?' (2001), 'World Order' (2014), 'Leadership' (2022). Regular attendee at World Economic Forum (Davos). Received Presidential Medal of Freedom (1977) and Medal of Liberty (1986). Currently burning in hell (d. November 29, 2023).

notes: George R. Eckard is an Executive Director in Capital Markets at Cushman & Wakefield, based in La Quinta, California. He holds a BA from UC Berkeley and has extensive experience in commercial real estate including property management, leasing, and valuations. He previously served as Senior Vice President at Colliers.

The company has grown to 160 acres in Tomales Bay and 90 acres in Humboldt Bay, producing over 5 million oysters annually and operating multiple restaurant locations.

He graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania with degrees in Economics and History. He serves on the boards of Hudson Pacific Properties and Playa Hotels & Resorts.

Janssens is a Belgian-born artist and educator who earned an MFA from the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Brussels, an MA from California State University, and a doctorate from the University of San Francisco. He has taught art at Merced College (Chair, Arts Division) and Diablo Valley College in Pleasant Hill, California, and maintains a studio in the San Francisco Bay Area.

name: Johnston, Scott Wallace
title: Fine Artist and Portrait Painter
notes: Scott Wallace Johnston (born 1961) is a California-based fine artist and portrait painter known for 'realistic impressionism' evocative of John Singer Sargent. He attended Art Center College of Design in Pasadena at the urging of family friend Millard Sheets and earned a BFA in Illustration. He has been a professional artist for over 30 years and is a member of the Portrait Society of America and Oil Painters of America.

name: Krames, Lawrence Arthur

notes: Lawrence Arthur Krames is a San Francisco otolaryngologist who founded Krames Communications in 1974. Krames became the market leader in patient education materials, producing over 1,400 titles used by over 80% of American hospitals and more than 300,000 physicians. The company has offices in San Bruno, California and Yardley, Pennsylvania.

name: Mahany, Brian Douglas
title: Founder, Commercial Photographer, Director, and Videographer
notes: Brian Douglas Mahany is a San Francisco Bay Area commercial advertising, fashion, and food photographer. He graduated from San Francisco State University (Dean's List, Fine Art in Photography) and studied under Jack Welpott. His clients include Salesforce, Adidas, Nike, Gap, PayPal, Levi's, eBay, and Facebook.

name: Marcelli, Victor Ottavio
title: Fine Artist and Oil Painter
notes: Victor Ottavio Marcelli (born September 11, 1939) is a Santa Rosa, California-based figurative and landscape oil painter. He holds a BA from UCLA and is devoted to capturing genre figure and landscape subjects en plein air. His father was Rico Marcelli, an orchestral conductor. He is a member of the Bohemian Club.

name: Mattos, John P.
title: Award-Winning Illustrator; Owner, John Mattos Illustration
notes: John P. Mattos is an award-winning San Francisco illustrator with a 43-year career known for his crisp, colorful retro style. He graduated with a BFA from Art Center College of Design in 1975 and has won over 100 awards, including a Gold Medal from the New York Society of Illustrators. He designed the 2006 USPS Olympic Stamp and has two posters in the Library of Congress permanent collection.

name: McCauley, Adam
title: Full Professor of Illustration, California College of the Arts
notes: Adam McCauley is a San Francisco-based illustrator, artist, and Full Professor at California College of the Arts. Born in 1965, he graduated from Parsons School of Design in 1987 and has been creating editorial and children's book illustrations since 1988. He won a Society of Illustrators Gold Medal and has illustrated the Time Warp Trio and Wayside School book series.

His 2020 New Yorker cover was named 'Most Controversial Magazine Cover' by the American Society of Magazine Editors. He holds a BFA from the University of Arizona (1989) and is in his fourth season as the San Francisco Opera's poster artist.

He studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and the Art Students League of New York under Frank Mason (1974-1979). His work is held in public and private collections worldwide including by Rolex and the Tennessee State Museum. He now resides in Franklin, Tennessee.

Bush (2001-2005). Currently Chairman of The Sage Group LLC.

Served as Chief of Thoracic Surgery at San Francisco General Hospital and Professor of Surgery at UCSF for decades. Published over 125 scientific articles; co-founded the Samson Thoracic Surgical Society (later Western Thoracic Surgical Association) in 1974. Pioneer in hyperbaric medicine.

notes: Born April 23, 1934 in El Paso, TX; died September 20, 2025 in Sun Valley, ID at age 91. Founded Tooley & Company in 1975, developing millions of square feet of premier office space across Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Orange County, and San Francisco. Earlier co-founded Ketchum, Peck & Tooley. Received Lifetime Achievement Award from LA Area Chamber of Commerce (1992).

Brooks Walker III is a San Francisco architect and philanthropist who founded Walker/Warner Architects specializing in residential architecture. University of Oregon BArch (1983). Active in conservation and arts organizations.

name: Wallis, Edward James
title: Founder / Owner
notes: UC graduate and former Napa Valley real estate developer. Purchased 85-acre property in Calistoga on Diamond Mountain Road in 1975. Planted vines in 1997 and founded Wallis Family Estate winery in 2006, producing under 1,000 cases annually of Cabernet Sauvignon. The estate's stone castle (built 1906) is on the National Register of Historic Places.

name: Alvarez, Walter
title: Professor Emeritus of Earth and Planetary Science
ngos: Founding member and former advisory board member of the International Big History Association (IBHA), a 501(c)(3) nonprofit.
notes: Walter Alvarez (born 1940) is the geologist who co-developed, with his father Nobel physicist Luis Alvarez, the impact theory that a large asteroid caused the Cretaceous-Paleogene mass extinction 66 million years ago. He joined the UC Berkeley faculty in 1981 and served as chairman of the Department of Geology and Geophysics from 1994 to 1997.

name: Augustine, Norman R.
title: Former Chairman and CEO
ngos: Former Chairman of the American Red Cross (nine years), Chairman of the National Academy of Engineering, President and Chairman of the Association of the United States Army, Chairman of the Aerospace Industries Association, Chairman of the Defense Science Board, former President of the Boy Scouts of America. Board of Trustees at Princeton, MIT, and Johns Hopkins (Trustee Emeritus). Regent of the University System of Maryland.
notes: Norman Augustine served as CEO of Lockheed Martin from 1996 to 1997 and as Chairman through 1998, having led the merger that created the company in 1995. He previously served as Under Secretary of the Army and held numerous leadership roles in the defense and aerospace industries.

name: Black, Clint
title: Country Music Singer, Songwriter, Producer
notes: Clint Black (born 1962) is an American country music superstar who has sold over 20 million records with 22 number-one career singles. He was signed to RCA Nashville in 1989 and later founded his own label, Equity Music Group, in 2003.

name: Bond, Charles
notes: Charles Bond is a member of the Pelican camp at Bohemian Grove; no reliable biographical or employer information was found through public records searches.

name: Burns, Ken
title: Co-Founder and Documentary Filmmaker
donations: Longtime supporter of the Democratic Party; described himself as a 'Yellow dog Democrat' and has contributed nearly $40,000 to Democratic causes. Made fundraising pitch for Vice President Kamala Harris in 2024. Produced the introductory video for Ted Kennedy at the 2008 Democratic National Convention.
notes: Ken Burns (born 1953) is an acclaimed American documentary filmmaker known for landmark PBS series including The Civil War, Baseball, Jazz, The Vietnam War, and Country Music. He co-founded Florentine Films in Walpole, New Hampshire in 1976. He has earned two Academy Award nominations and numerous Emmy Awards.

name: Callaghan, Kevin P.
title: Managing Director, Private Equity
ngos: Chairman of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
notes: Kevin P. Callaghan joined Berkshire Partners in 1987 and became a Managing Director in 1994. He has nearly 30 years of private equity experience and previously worked at Lehman Brothers. He holds a BSE from Princeton and an MBA from Stanford GSB.

name: Camargo, Carlos A. Jr.
employer: Massachusetts General Hospital / Harvard Medical School
title: Conn Chair in Emergency Medicine; Professor of Emergency Medicine and Epidemiology
ngos: Past president of the American College of Epidemiology; served on the 2005 US Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee.
notes: Dr. Carlos A. Camargo Jr. is the Conn Chair in Emergency Medicine at MGH and a Professor at Harvard Medical School and Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. He is founder and director of the Emergency Medicine Network (EMNet) and has an international reputation in respiratory/allergy emergencies and vitamin D research.

name: Case, Steve
title: Chairman and CEO
donations: Bipartisan approach; has maintained nonpartisan relationships with both Democrats and Republicans. Supported the Obama administration's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness.
ngos: Chairman of the Case Foundation (founded with wife Jean Case in 1997); former Chair of the Smithsonian Institution Board of Regents; both Cases joined The Giving Pledge in 2010.
notes: Steve Case (born 1958) co-founded America Online (AOL) in 1985 and orchestrated the AOL-Time Warner merger in 2000. After leaving AOL in 2003, he founded Revolution LLC, a Washington D.C.-based investment firm that has invested nearly $2 billion in companies including Anduril, Sweetgreen, DraftKings, and CLEAR.

name: Collins, G. Fulton IV
title: Chief Executive Officer
notes: G. Fulton Collins IV (also known as Fulton Collins) was appointed CEO of Wellfit, an Irving, Texas-based company, in April 2021. He previously served as Chairman and CEO of Network Communications Inc. (ApartmentFinder.com), President of Summit Acceptance (later CapitalOne Auto Finance), and held roles at Aegis Learning Group, Nestle, and E&J Gallo Winery. He holds a BA from UCLA and an MBA from Stanford GSB.

name: Cook, Scott
title: Co-Founder and Chairman of the Executive Committee
donations: Has donated to both parties; since the 1990s doubled donations to Republicans and Democrats, including maximum contributions to Mitt Romney and Harry Reid.
notes: Scott Cook (born 1952) co-founded Intuit in 1983 and served as its president and CEO until 1994. He currently serves as Chairman of the Executive Committee. He previously served on the boards of eBay (1998-2015) and Procter & Gamble (2000-2020). He holds a BS from USC and an MBA from Harvard Business School.

name: Evans, Richard B.
title: Former CEO, Alcan and Rio Tinto Alcan
ngos: Director of the United States Climate Action Partnership (USCAP); Chairman of the Environmental and Climate Change Committee of the Business Council of Canada; Chairman of the International Aluminium Institute and The Aluminum Association.
notes: Richard B. Evans served as CEO of Alcan Inc. from 2006 and then Rio Tinto Alcan from 2007 to 2009 following Rio Tinto's acquisition of Alcan. He later served as Interim Chairman and CEO of Constellium in 2011. He is a 42-year veteran of the aluminum industry, having previously spent 27 years with Kaiser Aluminum. He joined the CGI Group board of directors in 2009.

name: Grupe, Greenlaw 'Fritz' Jr.
title: Founder and Chairman
ngos: Regent of the University of the Pacific; founding chairman of UC Merced's foundation board of trustees; past president of the Stockton Chamber of Commerce.
notes: Greenlaw 'Fritz' Grupe Jr. founded The Grupe Company in Stockton, California in 1966 and has overseen the creation of 12 master-planned communities and more than 50,000 homes across 35 cities in six states. He served on President George H.W. Bush's Special Commission on Regulatory Barriers to Affordable Housing and received an honorary doctorate from CSU Stanislaus.

name: Hanson, Victor Davis
title: Martin and Illie Anderson Senior Fellow
donations: Conservative Republican commentator and Trump supporter; authored The Case for Trump (2019). Was formerly a registered Democrat, later a registered independent as of 2020, but has consistently supported Republican candidates and causes.
ngos: Member of the Bradley Foundation Board of Directors; served on the HF Guggenheim Foundation board for over a decade; Member of the Board of Advisors for the Independent Institute.
notes: Victor Davis Hanson (born 1953) is a classicist, military historian, and conservative political commentator. He is Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution focusing on classics and military history, and also holds an appointment at Pepperdine School of Public Policy. He received the National Humanities Medal in 2007 and the Bradley Prize in 2008.

name: Harlan, H. William
title: Founder and Chairman
notes: H. William 'Bill' Harlan (born 1940) is a Napa Valley vintner and real estate entrepreneur who founded Harlan Estate in 1984. He previously co-founded Pacific Union real estate in San Francisco and developed Meadowood resort. Harlan Estate is one of the world's most acclaimed wineries, producing Cabernet Sauvignon that has received multiple perfect scores. In 2021, he appointed his son Will as managing director while retaining his role as founder and chairman.

name: Herrington, John S.
employer: Retired; former Chairman, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich
title: Former U.S. Secretary of Energy; former Chairman
donations: Republican; served as Chairman of the California Republican Party after leaving government.
notes: John S. Herrington (born 1939) served as the 5th U.S. Secretary of Energy under President Reagan from 1985 to 1989. He previously served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy (1981-1983). After government service, he became Chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, overseeing a $2.8 billion restructuring, and later served as Chairman of the California Republican Party.

name: Jameson, James D.
title: President and Owner / International Director and Controlling Shareholder
donations: Republican; served as Assistant Secretary of Commerce under President George H.W. Bush.
ngos: Member, Board of Directors of the Reason Foundation; former Chairman, Institute of Americas Board of Trustees; Founding Circle member of the B612 Foundation (asteroid defense nonprofit). Former International President of Young Presidents' Organization (1989-90).
notes: James D. Jameson (born 1949) is an international entrepreneur and chairman/major shareholder of companies in aerospace, agriculture, publishing, and real estate, including Glenair Inc. (Glendale, CA), LIDCO Inc. (Brawley, CA), and the Luxembourg Cambridge Holding Group. He served as U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Development under President George H.W. Bush in 1992-93. He authored Capitalist at Large: Reflections of an International Entrepreneur.

notes: Gregory Glen Lau is a General Partner at WCAS, a leading healthcare and technology private equity firm founded in 1979. He joined WCAS in September 2017 after serving as Managing Director and head of fundraising at FFL Partners. He holds an A.B. cum laude in Mechanical Engineering from Harvard College (1999) and an MBA from Harvard Business School (2006).

Maymar is Executive Vice President of Compass Capital Corporation, an international asset finance and management company headquartered in San Francisco, California, specializing in financing and leasing transportation equipment. From 1988 to 1990 he was Executive Vice President and co-founder of Pegasus Capital Corporation. He holds an A.B. from Stanford University and an MBA from UC Berkeley.

name: McGarr, Cappy R.
title: President
donations: Democratic; appointed to Kennedy Center board by Presidents Clinton and Obama. Received National Medal of Arts from President Biden.
ngos: Board member of MD Anderson Cancer Center Board of Visitors; Board member of The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (appointed by Presidents Clinton and Obama); Board member of The Foundation for the National Archives; Board member of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Foundation.
notes: Cappy R. McGarr is an entrepreneur, fund manager, author, and Emmy-nominated producer based in Dallas, Texas. He serves as President of MCM Interests, LLC, an investment firm active in hedge funds and private equity for over 40 years. He is co-creator of the Kennedy Center Mark Twain Prize for American Humor and the Library of Congress Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. President Biden awarded him the National Medal of Arts in January 2025.

name: Rauner, Bruce V.

ngos: Trustee, Everglades Foundation; former lead of Chicago Public Education Fund.
notes: Bruce Rauner (born 1956) co-founded and served as Chairman of Chicago-based private equity firm GTCR from 1981 to 2012, helping finance over 200 companies. He served as the 42nd Governor of Illinois from 2015 to 2019 as a Republican. He lost his 2018 re-election bid to JB Pritzker by a large margin. He is now a private investor and trustee of the Everglades Foundation.

name: Runnels, Charles (Duke) B. III
title: Managing Director
notes: Charles 'Duke' Runnels III is the son of Pepperdine University Chancellor Emeritus Charles B. Runnels. Duke Runnels serves as Managing Director at TR Winston, a financial services firm based in Bedminster, New Jersey. He previously served as President of FORT Properties, Inc. and held positions at CBRE Investors and Oxford Properties.

name: Salestrom, James Kevin
title: Singer-Songwriter
notes: James Kevin Salestrom (February 20, 1956 - November 22, 2023) was an Emmy Award-winning American singer-songwriter and guitarist. He co-founded the country-folk rock band Timberline in 1971 and later joined Dolly Parton's touring band in 1979, performing with her through the 1980s. He performed for five U.S. Presidents and was a noted skiing ambassador for Colorado. He died of cancer in Arvada, Colorado.

name: Sandman, John Berthean 'Bert'

donations: Republican; has donated to the National Republican Senatorial Committee, the Republican National Committee, and GOPAC. Member of conservative clubs including Burning Tree and The Brook.
notes: B. Francis (Bernard Francis) Saul II is the grandson of the founder of the B.F. Saul Company, a major Washington D.C.-area real estate empire. He took over the company in 1969 and has been Chairman and CEO of Saul Centers (NYSE: BFS), a self-managed REIT, since 1993. He sold Chevy Chase Bank to Capital One in 2009. As of early 2025, Forbes estimated his net worth at $2.8 billion.

name: Saxton, Andrew E. J.
employer: King George Financial Corporation / Saxton Capital Corporation
title: CEO / President

He is currently CEO of King George Financial Corporation, President of Saxton Capital Corporation, and President of Upper Island Development Ltd. He began his career in finance with Credit Suisse in Switzerland and New York.

name: Simpson, Alan K.
title: Former U.S. Senator; Attorney
donations: Republican; served as Senate Republican Whip. Known for bipartisan efforts including Simpson-Bowles deficit commission.
ngos: Board member, Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget; Board member, National Institute for Civil Discourse; co-chair, advisory board, Issue One; Board member, Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts; Smithsonian Institution Board of Regents; former member, Buffalo Bill Historical Center board; former member, Grand Teton Music Festival board.
notes: Alan K. Simpson (September 2, 1931 - March 14, 2025) served as U.S. Senator from Wyoming (Republican) from 1979 to 1997 and was Senate Republican Whip from 1985 to 1995. After the Senate he taught at Harvard's Kennedy School (1997-2000). He co-chaired the Simpson-Bowles National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform in 2010. He died in Cody, Wyoming at age 93.

name: Smith, Richard W.
title: Principal (Co-Founder)
notes: Richard W. 'Rick' Smith is a co-founder and Principal of Cannon Street Investigations, a San Francisco-based investigative firm he founded in 1996 with fellow former FBI agent Bill Buchanan. He served as an FBI Special Agent from 1970 to the mid-1990s, specializing in Soviet counterintelligence and espionage. He later served as Media Representative for the San Francisco FBI Division during major cases including the Polly Klaas kidnapping and UNABOM investigation.

name: Spencer, Hunter

notes: Hunter Spencer is a licensed general contractor and owner of Sunbrite Construction in Novato, California. He is a fourth-generation member of the William H. Donner family and serves on the board of the Donner family foundation. He is also a beekeeper and is active in the Novato Police Explorer Post.

name: Trent, D. Michael
notes: D. Michael Trent is a member of the Pelican camp at Bohemian Grove. He may be related to Darrell M. Trent (who has a son Michael Trent listed as Vice President at Acton Development, Inc.), but no independent biographical record was confirmed for D. Michael Trent specifically.

name: Trent, Darrell M.
title: Chairman of the Board and CEO
donations: Republican; served in Nixon and Reagan administrations. Nominated by President Reagan as U.S. Ambassador (1983).
ngos: Former board of regents, Pepperdine University (1985-1992); former board of directors, Foundation for Teaching Economics (1988-1990); former deputy chairman, Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation (1985-1988).
notes: Darrell M. Trent (born August 2, 1938) is an American ambassador, academic administrator, and transportation executive. He served in the Nixon White House as Deputy Assistant to the President (1969-1973) and as Deputy Secretary of Transportation under Reagan. He served as a volunteer with the Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq in 2003 to help rebuild Iraq's Ministry of Transportation. Since 1988 he has been Chairman and CEO of Acton Development Company, Inc., a private real estate development firm.

notes: James 'Jake' Walker IV is a California State Bar Certified Specialist in Estate Planning, Trust, and Probate Law who has practiced in Marin County for over 45 years. A San Francisco native, he is a partner at DeMartini Walker & Ghaedi LLP in San Rafael, California. He received a B.A. from the University of Virginia and a J.D. from UC Hastings College of the Law.

ngos: National Geographic Society Explorers Council; International League of Conservation Photographers (Fellow); Explorers Club (Honorary Member); Royal Canadian Geographical Society (Honorary Vice-President); Voices for Biodiversity (Advisory Board)
notes: Edmund Wade Davis is a Canadian cultural anthropologist, ethnobotanist, photographer, and author. He served as Explorer-in-Residence at the National Geographic Society (2000-2013) and is currently a professor at UBC. Best known for his 1985 book The Serpent and the Rainbow. His 2012 book Into the Silence: The Great War, Mallory and the Conquest of Everest won the Baillie Gifford Prize for non-fiction. He holds degrees from Harvard in anthropology, biology, and a PhD in ethnobotany.

name: Empey, Gordon Hume
title: Chief Operating Officer and Partner / General Counsel
notes: Gordon Hume Empey was appointed COO of Frazier Life Sciences in 2025, having served as Partner and General Counsel since December 2017. He has over 25 years of experience advising venture capital investors and life sciences companies. Prior to Frazier he was a partner at Cooley LLP (2008-2017) and previously VP and General Counsel at Radiant Research (2004-2007). He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy Judge Advocate General Corps (1994-1998). He holds a JD from UC Berkeley School of Law (1994) and is based in the Seattle, Washington area.

name: Empey, Morgan H.
title: Account Director
notes: Morgan H. Empey is an Account Director at Salesforce based in Irvine, California. He is a UC Berkeley alumnus and previously held roles at Oracle, VectorUSA, and Navisite. Likely related to Gordon Hume Empey (same Rendezvous camp).

name: Fama, Glenn J.
employer: Fama & Co. Capital Wealth Management (Wells Fargo Advisors Financial Network)
title: Chairman, Managing Director, and Principal
notes: Glenn J. Fama founded Fama & Co. Capital Wealth Management in early 2008, a boutique investment advisory firm on Montgomery Street in San Francisco affiliated with Wells Fargo Advisors Financial Network. He has over 35 years of investment advisory experience, having previously held senior managing director and portfolio management positions at Paine Webber (1986-1996), First Union (1996-2000), and UBS (2000-2007). He holds a BS in Finance from the University of Nevada and holds a California Insurance License.

name: Forster, Nicholas S.
title: Co-Founder and Host; Musician
ngos: Colorado Bluegrass Music Society (Hall of Honor inductee); eTown (founder)
notes: Nicholas S. Forster is widely known as Nick Forster, co-founder and host of eTown, a nationally syndicated NPR multimedia production company based in Boulder, Colorado. He is also a founding member and bassist of the acclaimed bluegrass band Hot Rize (formed 1978), which earned a Grammy nomination in 1991 and won IBMA Entertainer of the Year. Hot Rize was inducted into the Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame in 2025. He was born in Beirut in 1955 and raised in upstate New York before relocating to Colorado in the mid-1970s.

name: Gregory, David
employer: CNN; American University School of International Service
title: Political Analyst (CNN); Adjunct Professor
notes: David Michael Gregory (born August 24, 1970) is an American television journalist who moderated NBC's Meet the Press from December 2008 to August 2014. He previously served as NBC's Chief White House Correspondent during the George W. Bush and early Obama presidencies, and broke the story when Vice President Biden publicly endorsed same-sex marriage in 2012. He joined CNN as a political analyst in March 2016. He also teaches at American University's School of International Service and has taught at Georgetown and Tufts. He earned his BA in International Studies from American University in 1992.

name: Haller, Thomas F. Jr.
notes: Thomas F. Haller Jr. is the son of Thomas Frank Haller (1937-2004), the MLB All-Star catcher who became VP of Baseball Operations and General Manager of the San Francisco Giants (1981-1985) and later GM of the Chicago White Sox. Tom Haller Jr. worked in real estate and finance from 1982 to 2001 with The San Francisco Giants, The Lurie Company, GE Commercial Real Estate Finance, and Cargill Financial Services Corporation. He resides in Indian Wells, California.

notes: Jerome Neal Herrick is a resident of Piedmont, California. Public records show associations with K.S.D. Atlantic Transport Systems and Meran Technology. Limited additional public profile available.

name: Lerude, Warren Leslie
title: Professor Emeritus, Reynolds School of Journalism
ngos: Nevada Press Association (Hall of Fame inductee, 1998); Nevada Board of Regents (appointed 2020)
notes: Warren Leslie Lerude (born October 29, 1937) is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and professor emeritus at UNR's Reynolds School of Journalism. He shared the 1977 Pulitzer Prize for Editorial Writing for a series attacking brothel owner Joe Conforte of the Mustang Ranch. He served as publisher of the Reno Evening Gazette and Nevada State Journal under Gannett, and was an inaugural editorial board member of USA Today. He taught at UNR from 1981 to 2009. He authored books including American Commander in Spain (1986) and Robert Laxalt: The Story of a Storyteller (2013). He served as a Pulitzer juror seven times.

name: Littlefield, Edmund W. Jr.

notes: Edmund W. Littlefield Jr. is a philanthropist and musician who directs the Sage Foundation (Arlington, WA). He is Vice President of the Edmund & Jeannik Littlefield Foundation, a California-based private foundation established in 1958. His father Edmund Wattis Littlefield (1914-2001) was CEO of Utah Construction & Mining Co. who orchestrated its landmark 1976 merger with General Electric â€” the largest corporate merger in U.S. history at that time â€” creating Utah International Inc. His father appeared on the Forbes 400 list with a net worth of $2.3 billion in 2001.

notes: John Brownlee Lovewell founded The Lovewell Company in September 1987, a Silicon Valley commercial real estate development firm investing in speculative office, R&D, and retail projects. In a joint venture called Keenan Lovewell Ventures, the firm developed approximately 1,400,000 square feet across ten projects. He previously served as VP/President of Argus Financial Corporation and spent eight years at Union Bank. He is a UC Berkeley graduate with an MBA from San Francisco State University and resides in Atherton, California. He served in the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War.

title: Chief Advisor / Founder
ngos: Society for Science (Board of Trustees, joined 2021); Manifold Fund (founder)
notes: Charles K. McCabe is the great-grandson of E.W. Scripps, who founded the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain and the United Press wire service. He established the Manifold Fund in 2018 to continue the Scripps family tradition of scientific philanthropy. He previously specialized in Northern California investment real estate sales for over 30 years, managing the acquisition or disposition of more than 7.6 million square feet of commercial properties and over 20,000 acres of vacant land. He operated San Francisco Capital Advisors at 2 Embarcadero Center. Not to be confused with Charles McCabe (1915-1983), the San Francisco Chronicle columnist.

name: Merten, John R.

notes: John R. Merten is CEO of Studio Green, a licensed landscape architectural design firm based in San Anselmo, California. He has 30 years of experience in landscape architecture spanning estate residential, commercial, public parks and schools. He previously was a Partner at Barclays Private Equity. He holds a BS in Landscape Architecture from California Polytechnic State University.

name: Merten, Peter B.
title: Group Vice President, Donnelley Solutions
notes: Peter B. Merten is Group Vice President of the Donnelley Solutions Group at RR Donnelley & Sons. He holds a BA in Diplomacy and Foreign Affairs from Miami University (1980-1984). He previously held roles at Litho Industries, an RR Donnelley company. Likely related to John R. Merten (same Rendezvous camp).

name: Morrish, William B.
employer: Parsons School of Design, The New School (retired); Invested Public Network
title: Dean Emeritus, School of Constructed Environments; Professor of Urban Ecologies
ngos: Charlottesville Community Design Center (collaborator); Places Journal (contributing author)
notes: William B. Morrish is an architect, urban designer, and professor recognized by the New York Times architecture critic Herbert Muschamp in 1994 as 'the most valuable thinker in urbanism today.' He served as Dean of the School of Constructed Environments at Parsons The New School for Design and previously held the Elwood R. Quesada Chair at the University of Virginia School of Architecture. His work has focused on public infrastructure as cultural landscape, Phoenix Public Art Works, the World Trade Center redesign process, and Hurricane Katrina rebuilding in New Orleans. He is a graduate of UC Berkeley (B.Arch 1971) and Harvard Graduate School of Design (M.Arch in Urban Design 1978).

name: Mott, Brian T.
title: President and Chief Executive Officer
notes: Brian T. Mott founded Langtech Systems Consulting in 1987 in San Francisco, providing IT managed services, cybersecurity, custom software development, and AI solutions to businesses. His career began at Oracle Corporation where he developed large-scale manufacturing and control systems using relational database technology. He holds an MBA in Information Technology from UCLA. Langtech is headquartered at 733 Front Street, Suite 110, San Francisco, California.

name: Olivier, Frank
title: Comedy Juggler; Entertainer
notes: Frank Olivier is a three-time world juggling champion and performer whose act combines stand-up comedy, award-winning juggling, magic, unicycling, and prop comedy. He began his career on the streets of San Francisco, attended Ringling Bros. & Barnum and Bailey Clown College, and shared stages with Robin Williams, Dana Carvey, and Whoopi Goldberg. He appeared in the Broadway touring production of Sugar Babies (with Mickey Rooney) and on the Tonight Show, HBO's Just for Laughs, America's Got Talent, PBS, BBC, and Disney. He is based in the San Francisco Bay Area.

name: Phipps, Allen M.

notes: Allen M. Phipps is a management consultant based in Menlo Park (Palo Alto), California. He is a former CEO of SRI Consulting (President & CEO, June 1995 to January 2002) and a former Partner at The Boston Consulting Group. He specializes in strategy development and organizational design for middle market companies and non-profits. He is a nationally recognized keynote speaker and author of 25 publications and 5 books. He is a Stanford University Graduate School of Business alumnus.

notes: Richard A. Saffir is a San Francisco-based attorney (California Bar #133899) and technology executive. He currently serves as Chief Legal Officer at Kavia AI. His career has spanned multiple tech and telecom companies including PeakNet, PT Holding Company, Odyssey Telecorp, Osprey Management & Capital, and Wurl. He has launched four start-up companies. He holds an LLM in Tax Law from New York University (1986-1987).

He was previously West Coast regional team leader for GMO's Global Client Relations team in Berkeley, co-founder and COO of RBI Capital Management, and Executive Vice President/Co-Head of North American Client Relations at Capital Guardian Trust Company (Capital Group). Earlier in his career he was a Vice President at Goldman Sachs Group. He holds a BA in Economics from Colorado College (class of 1985) and an MBA from Harvard Business School.

notes: Cabot Brown (b. 1961, San Francisco) is an investment banker with 30+ years in healthcare finance. He co-founded and ran healthcare investment banking practices at Volpe Welty, Seven Hills Partners, and GCA Savvian before founding Carabiner LLC. He served as a non-executive director of GW Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ: GWPH) from 2013 until its acquisition by Jazz Pharmaceuticals. He holds an AB cum laude from Harvard and an MBA with high distinction from Harvard Business School.

notes: Steven K. Buster (b. 1950, Orange County, CA) spent 35 years in banking including stints in London with First Interstate Bank and Singapore with Standard Chartered Bank. He served as CEO of Mechanics Bank (Richmond, CA) from 2004 until later, during which time the bank substantially grew profits. He also served a two-year term as COO for the Los Angeles County District Attorney and is currently at Grosvenor Property Americas.

name: Butler, Vincent K. III
title: Founder / Real Estate Developer
notes: Vincent 'Buzz' K. Butler III founded Lake Street Company, a Northern California real estate development firm specializing in creative mixed-use retail, commercial, multi-family, industrial, and office projects. Notable projects include Hidden Brook Golf Course in Vallejo, West Gate Mixed Use in San Leandro, and the Napa Valley Gateway Business Park.

name: Campbell, Duncan H.
title: Founder / Investor
ngos: Friends of the Children (founder)
notes: Duncan Campbell grew Campbell Global, a timberland investment management firm responsible for more than 3.1 million acres of land worldwide before selling it. After the sale he founded Friends of the Children, an organization providing paid mentors to at-risk youth. He graduated from the University of Oregon.

name: Cerruti, Thomas E. K.
title: Attorney / Partner
ngos: Order of St. John (OStJ)
notes: Thomas E. K. Cerruti (b. February 20, 1952, Berkeley, CA) earned a BA from Claremont McKenna College (1974) and a JD from UC Hastings College of Law (1977). He is an active California Bar member (bar no. 127140, admitted 1987) practicing in La Jolla, California, specializing in business law, cooperatives, and real estate matters. He also holds the Order of St. John.

name: Charles, Glen G.
title: Co-Creator / Writer / Producer
notes: Glen Charles (b. February 8, 1943, Henderson, NV) co-created the NBC sitcom Cheers (1982-1993) with his brother Les Charles and director James Burrows under the Charles/Burrows/Charles production company. He and Les previously wrote for M*A*S*H, The Mary Tyler Moore Show, and Taxi. They won multiple Emmy Awards for Outstanding Comedy Series and Outstanding Writing.

name: Drakoulias, George
title: Record Producer / A&R Executive
notes: George Drakoulias (b. 1965, Syosset, NY) is a music producer and former A&R executive at American Recordings (Rick Rubin's label). He signed and produced The Black Crowes' debut album Shake Your Money Maker (5M+ US copies), The Jayhawks, and The Freewheelers, and also produced records for Primal Scream, Screaming Trees, Dan Penn, and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers.

name: Eberhardt, Douglass M. II
title: Chairman and CEO
ngos: University of the Pacific Board of Regents
notes: Douglass M. Eberhardt II graduated from University of the Pacific (1989) and became the 9th president in Bank of Stockton's 157-year history (California's oldest bank still operating under its original charter, founded 1867). He worked his way up from a management trainee at Bank of New York before returning to lead the family institution. His father Douglass M. Eberhardt I was the previous chairman and CEO.

name: Engs, Stuart R. Jr.

notes: Stuart Rawlings Engs (b. May 28, 1935, Oakland, CA; d. May 15, 2016, San Francisco) attended Cate School and UC Berkeley and served as a U.S. Marine Corps Captain. He spent most of his adult life in Reno, Nevada as owner of Truck Parts & Equipment Co. and was appointed by the Governor to the Nevada State Gaming Commission from 1979-1984.

name: Fish, Jason M.

Previously he was a managing member at Farallon Capital Management (1992-2000) and a Senior Vice President at Lehman Brothers. He co-founded Alliance Partners LLC in 2011 and serves as President of Sebastes Capital Management.

He attended Stanford University and UC Davis (farming economics), then managed family ranches in Napa County including the Knoxville Mine before establishing a family office in San Francisco. He was a former trustee of the Bay Area Discovery Museum and the Bancroft Library.

name: Hauser, W. Kurt

notes: W. Kurt Hauser (BA and MBA from Stanford) is a San Francisco-based investment economist and chairman of Wentworth, Hauser & Violich, an investment management firm. He is Chairman Emeritus of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and known for 'Hauser's Law,' his empirical observation that US federal revenues remain roughly constant as a percentage of GDP regardless of top marginal tax rates.

name: Jones, Ellis

notes: Ellis B. Jones (Yale School of Management, UC Berkeley) spent 25+ years in investment banking and private equity. He was Head of West Coast Investment Banking at Wasserstein Perella and earlier ran the Los Angeles Investment Banking and Hotel/Gaming Group at Salomon Brothers (1988-1994). He co-founded Wasserstein & Co. in 2001 and served as CEO through 2012, then became Chairman. He served on Lazard's Board of Directors and previously on the boards of IMAX, Odwalla, and All-Clad.

name: Kuechler, Henry N. IV

His father, Henry Norbury Kuechler III (1938-2015), was the former president and owner of Knob Hill Mines. The Kuechler family has operated in California since the early 1900s.

notes: Weyman Ivan Lundquist (1930-2019) graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth (1952) and earned his JD from Harvard Law School (1955). A Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, he was admitted to practice in Massachusetts, Alaska, California, and Vermont. His practice areas included financial markets, consumer protection, and complex litigation. In his later years he became Managing Director of Technology Licensing Division at West Coast Magnetics in Stockton, CA.

Total FEC donations to Democratic candidates over $419,000 since 1985. Also received PPP loan enforcement action from Justice Department.
ngos: Broadcasting Board of Governors (appointed by President Obama, confirmed December 2014); active in numerous Democratic Party fundraising committees

Deputy Finance Chair of the Democratic National Committee. PRWeek's PR Pro of the Year (2015). Named to PRWeek Hall of Fame (2020).

Holds a B.S. in Finance from Santa Clara University and completed the Agribusiness Seminar at Harvard Business School Executive Education. Co-founded Sun Valley Rice with his father. Longtime activist for California water issues. Author of A Rice Conversation.

name: Lake, Peyton Myers
notes: Mineral rights holder in Tyler, TX (4 mineral interests across 6 counties on file). Also associated with Burleson Partners, LLC (Tyler, TX).

name: Lindberg, Eric John Jr.

ngos: Cal Poly Rodeo Board; California Rangeland Trust; Past Chapter Chair, YPO Golden Gate Chapter (San Francisco)

Co-CEO from January 2006-December 2018, CEO January 2019-December 2022, Interim President and CEO October 2024-February 2025, Chairman of the Board since January 2023. Under his leadership, Grocery Outlet grew store count by 259% and revenues by 484%.

Joined Ares Management in 2021. Acquired more than $9 billion of commercial real estate during career. Retired from Ares board effective February 1, 2025. B.S. from University of Southern California; MBA from UCLA Anderson School.

Co-founded Folio Fine Wine Partners with father Michael, mother Isabel, and sister Dina in 2004. Previously served as Director of Marketing at Robert Mondavi Corporation. B.A. in English Literature from Santa Clara University. Also on advisory board of Napa Valley Cannabis Association.

name: O'Neill, George D. Jr.
title: Founder

notes: Great-grandson of John D. Rockefeller Jr.; sculptor, jewelry maker, and pilot. Manages small family agriculture and construction materials operations in Lake Wales, FL. Identified as 'U.S. Person 2' in the Maria Butina/Russian foreign agent case (hosted a private dinner during the 2017 National Prayer Breakfast attended by Russian central bank head Alexander Torshin). Conservative author; contributor to The American Conservative. Estimated net worth $200 million.

name: Rennick, Mark Eugene
title: Owner and President
notes: Known professionally as Mark 'Mooka' Rennick. Founded Prairie Sun Recording Studios in Cotati, California (1978/1980). Recording studio situated on a 10-acre former chicken farm with three studios. Notable artists recorded include Tom Waits (Bone Machine, 1992 Grammy winner for Best Alternative), Paul McCartney, Van Morrison, Carlos Santana, Huey Lewis and the News, Nine Inch Nails, and many others. Also worked as musician and bass player touring with Commander Cody's Billy C. Farlow in the late 1970s. Attended Sonoma State University.

notes: Born June 7, 1939. Spent 40+ years at Dykema Gossett law firm, serving six+ years as chairman and CEO before retiring in 2004. Joined University of Detroit Mercy law faculty, became dean in 2009. Served as Councilman and mayor pro tempore of Grosse Pointe Farms, Michigan (1975-1983). Specializes in business law and mergers and acquisitions.

name: Starling, Christopher A. USMC (Ret)

ngos: Board of Trustees, San Francisco Maritime National Park Association; Board of Advisors, Veteran Launch; Board member, Main Street Launch; Mentor, Creative Destruction Lab

Ten overseas deployments including three combat tours (Operations Desert Shield, Desert Storm, Iraqi Freedom). Commanded 2nd Battalion, 2nd Marines (Camp Lejeune) and 23rd Marine Regiment (San Bruno, CA). National Security Affairs Fellow, Hoover Institution, 2007-2008. Testified before Congress (June 22, 2023) on veteran employment in cybersecurity. B.A. in Modern Languages, Virginia Military Institute; M.P.A., City University of New York.

Founded Litigation Sciences, Inc. and DecisionQuest. Former Professor at UCLA Graduate School of Management (Associate Professor of Marketing) and USC Graduate School of Business (Chairman, Department of Marketing). Visiting Professor of Law, Tulane University. Also founded Vinson Litigation Finance (also known as Vinson Resolution Management). Appointed by California Governor Pete Wilson to California Commission on Judicial Performance. Participates in Federalist Society events.

He previously served as CFO of AstraZeneca (1997-2007), Partner and Managing Director at Goldman Sachs, CFO of Novartis AG (2009-2013), and Deputy Group Chairman of HSBC (2018-2020). He is a former Partner at KPMG. He was appointed CBE for services to business.

name: Turner, Marshall C. Jr.
title: Independent Technology Venture Investor
ngos: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (Board Chair); Corporation for Public Broadcasting (Board); KQED Inc. (Board Chair); PBS (Board); George Lucas Educational Foundation (Board)
notes: Marshall C. Turner Jr. holds a B.S. and M.S. from Stanford (1964, 1965) and an M.B.A. from Harvard (1970). He served as a White House Fellow, helped found the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and served as CEO of Liquid Crystal Technology (1975-1980). He chaired the boards of the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (Reagan nominee), KQED Inc., and Reed Union School District.

name: Wagener, Peter Davis
title: Relationship Manager
notes: Peter Davis Wagener is a Relationship Manager at First Republic Bank in the San Francisco Bay Area, with a background in regional banking management and relationship management at major financial institutions.

name: Berry, Kenneth G.
title: Financial professional / Options floor broker
notes: Kenneth Anthony Berry (b. July 5, 1942, San Francisco Bay Area; d. 2019) attended St. Ignatius Preparatory High School and the University of San Francisco. He worked as an OTC trader for Reynolds and Co. (later Mitchum, Templeton & Jones) and ended his career as an options floor broker on the Pacific Coast Exchange. He was active as a youth athletic coach in Moraga, CA.

name: Cella, Peter Michael
title: President and CEO
notes: Peter Michael Cella is President and CEO of Beere & Purves Inc., one of California's largest insurance General Agencies (founded 1929), headquartered in Walnut Creek, CA. He holds a BS from UC Berkeley (1980-1984). The Cella family has a long history in the California wine industry.

name: DeVoto, Randall B.
title: Principal / Co-founder
notes: Randall B. DeVoto, AIA, LEED AP, is a co-founding principal of CSDA Design Group (the 'D' stands for DeVoto) in San Francisco. A native San Franciscan with a BS in Architecture from Washington State University (1975), he has been with the firm for over 50 years and helped establish its educational facilities and airport noise insulation practice.

name: Decker, Frederick S.
title: Vice President and Wealth Advisor
notes: Frederick 'Fred' S. Decker is a Vice President and Wealth Advisor at J.P. Morgan Wealth Management in San Francisco, CA with over 24 years of industry experience. He holds a BA in Political Science from UCLA and an MA in International Finance from Thunderbird School of Global Management. Prior to J.P. Morgan (2008+), he held VP positions at Wells Fargo (1989-1999) and Merrill Lynch (1999-2008).

name: Graham, Stephen A.
title: President and Founder
notes: Stephen A. Graham is President of CrossHill Financial Group, a private merchant bank he founded in 1988. He previously held positions at Kidder, Peabody & Co., Merrill Lynch, and Arthur Young & Co. He served on the board of TNS, Inc. (NYSE-listed) from 2003-2013 including as chairman of the audit committee.

name: Hanley, John A. Jr.
title: Retired Executive
ngos: Hanley Foundation (substance abuse treatment nonprofit, West Palm Beach, FL)
notes: John 'Jack' A. Hanley Sr. (1922-2018) served as President, Chairman and CEO of Monsanto Company (1972-1983) after a career at Procter & Gamble. He served on the boards of Armco Steel, P&G, Southern Pacific, Citicorp, Citibank, May Department Stores, and R.J. Nabisco. 'John A. Hanley Jr.' in the Skiddoo list is likely his son, with limited independent public biography found.

name: Healey, Terry J.
title: Author, Keynote Speaker, and Business Strategist
notes: Terry J. Healey is a UC Berkeley graduate (BA) with a 35-year career as a marketing executive, including a founding team role at a company that achieved an IPO. He survived a rare disfiguring cancer at age 21, leading to over 30 surgeries, and later became a professional speaker and author of 'The Resilience Mindset.' He lives in Santa Cruz, CA.

name: Hoyem, Andrew L.
title: Founder and Publisher (retired)
ngos: Grabhorn Institute (co-founder, emeritus); Grolier Club; Roxburghe Club; American Printing History Association
notes: Andrew Lewison Hoyem (born December 1, 1935) is a typographer, letterpress printer, publisher, and poet. He founded Arion Press in San Francisco in 1974 with equipment from the historic Grabhorn Press, publishing 113 limited-edition fine-press books including Moby-Dick and Ulysses. In 2000 he co-founded the nonprofit Grabhorn Institute to preserve typefounding and letterpress printing; the facility is recognized by the National Trust for Historic Preservation as an 'irreplaceable cultural treasure.' He retired from both in 2018.

name: Hughan, Wade C.
title: Partner / CPA
ngos: Order of Malta - Western Association (Secretary General)
notes: Wade C. Hughan is a CPA and co-founder of Barlow & Hughan LLP, an independent accounting firm in San Francisco. He began his career at one of the original Big Eight accounting firms (Deloitte, Haskins & Sells), working in San Francisco and then London, and formed the partnership in 1990. He is licensed in California (CPA #39063).

name: Jagels, Edward R.
employer: Retired (formerly Kern County District Attorney's Office)
title: District Attorney (retired)
donations: Republican; strong advocate for conservative criminal justice policies; no specific FEC large-donor records identified.
notes: Edward R. Jagels (born March 26, 1949) served as Kern County District Attorney from 1983 to 2010, making him the county's longest-sitting DA. A Republican and 'get tough on crime' prosecutor based in Bakersfield, CA, he was influential in promoting victims' rights, the death penalty, and California's three strikes law. His tenure was also marked by controversial wrongful convictions in child sex abuse cases, and Kern County later paid $10 million in settlements to wrongfully convicted individuals.

name: Judson, David William
title: Senior Advisor / Journalist / Editor
notes: David William Judson is a journalist and editor who covered Congress, the White House, and politics for Gannett Newspapers/USA Today in Washington, D.C. from the late 1980s to 2000. He subsequently became editor-in-chief of the Hurriyet Daily News (Turkey's leading English-language paper, 2006-2013) and then editor-in-chief of Stratfor Geopolitical Forecasting in Austin (2013-2018). He is now a senior advisor at Global Foresight.

name: Leland, Hayne E.
employer: UC Berkeley Haas School of Business (Emeritus)
title: Professor Emeritus of Finance
notes: Hayne Ellis Leland is Professor Emeritus (Arno Rayner Chair) at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business. He received his AB from Harvard, an MSc (Econ) from the London School of Economics, and a PhD in Economics from Harvard. In 1979, he pioneered 'portfolio insurance,' a dynamic hedging strategy based on options pricing theory, and co-founded Leland O'Brien Rubinstein Associates (LOR) in 1980. He and his LOR partners were named Fortune 'Businessmen of the Year' in 1987. He received the inaugural Stephen A. Ross Prize in Financial Economics (2008) and was named IAQF/Northfield Financial Engineer of the Year (2016).

name: MacDonald, Kirkpatrick
title: Managing General Partner
ngos: Friends of UC (donor/supporter); Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin (Officier Commandeur Commanderie de Bordeaux)
notes: Kirkpatrick MacDonald is Managing General Partner of MacDonald & Cie, a real estate investment firm. He holds degrees from Yale University (Industrial Administration/Engineering), Oxford University (Politics, Philosophy & Economics), and completed PhD studies in Political Economy at the Institut Universitaire de Hautes Etudes Internationales in Geneva. He previously worked at Lehman Brothers Consulting Partners (affiliate of Loeb Rhoades & Co.) and Morgan Guaranty International Finance Corporation.

name: Malott, Deane
title: Marketing Director / Communications Manager
ngos: NOLS (National Outdoor Leadership School) - Board of Trustees (2025+)
notes: Deane Malott of Menlo Park, CA is a marketing director who worked at Novariant (GPS technology company) as a communications manager. He is a NOLS (National Outdoor Leadership School) Board of Trustees member since September 2025. His connection to NOLS dates back decades to a backpacking course in the Wind River Mountains. He is likely a descendant of Deane Waldo Malott (1898-1996), the 6th President of Cornell University.

notes: Skip Mancini (Brooks T. Mancini Jr.) is the President and Owner of B.T. Mancini Co., Inc., one of the largest independent commercial flooring and specialty contractors in the United States, operating throughout Northern California and Nevada. He joined the family business in 1983, became President in 2000, and purchased it from his father (Brooks Sr.) in 2005. He holds a BS from UC Berkeley (1979-1983) and is based in Milpitas, CA.

title: Attorney (inactive)
notes: James McNab III is a California real estate attorney based in Santa Rosa, CA (office at 2455 Bennett Valley Rd, Suite B301). He was licensed in 1974 and is currently listed as inactive with no misconduct found. His bar number is 62098.

name: Mel, Howard Charles
title: Professor Emeritus of Biophysics
notes: Howard Charles Mel (January 14, 1926 - May 3, 2023) was a lifelong Berkeley native and Professor of Biophysics Emeritus at UC Berkeley. He attended UC Berkeley, served in Naval ROTC, and helped run the Naval Intelligence office in Bremen, Germany during WWII. He returned to UC Berkeley, earning a BS in Physical Chemistry (1948), and worked at Donner Lab. He later helped establish an undergraduate program in bioengineering at Berkeley. He was a partner in several wineries and served on the UC Faculty Club's wine committee into his emeritus years.

Detailed public biography was not found in current web searches.

name: Murphy, Leo J.
title: Counsel (Litigation Services)
ngos: The Guardsmen - Life Member, Past Director, Hall of Fame; Mission Dolores Academy - former two-term director
notes: Leo J. Murphy Jr. is Counsel in the Litigation Services Department at Murphy Pearson Bradley & Feeney in San Francisco. He advises manufacturers on product liability law and represents insurers and financial institutions. He holds a JD and BA from the University of San Francisco. He is rated AV Preeminent by Martindale-Hubbell and listed in The Best Lawyers in America (2019-2020). He is a life member and past director of The Guardsmen (a San Francisco Bay Area youth charity), and is in The Guardsmen Hall of Fame.

name: Nash, Jeffrey P.
title: Managing Director and Private Wealth Advisor
notes: Jeffrey P. Nash is a Managing Director, Private Wealth Advisor, Senior Portfolio Manager, and Retirement Plan Consultant at UBS Financial Services Inc. in San Francisco, CA (555 California Street). He has been with UBS for approximately 38 years. He graduated from UC Davis and is a FINRA Arbitrator and 2020/2021 NFL PA Registered Players Financial Advisor.

name: Nichols, Alan Hammond
employer: Law Office of Alan Hammond Nichols (retired)
title: Attorney (retired) / 42nd President, The Explorers Club
ngos: The Explorers Club (42nd President, 2012); Sacred Mountain Foundation (President); San Francisco School Board (former President); City College of San Francisco (former President)
notes: Alan Hammond Nichols (born February 14, 1930) is a Stanford-educated attorney (BA 1951, Phi Beta Kappa; JD 1955, Stanford Law Review), Korean War veteran (47th Infantry Division, Lieutenant), and explorer. He practiced law in the San Francisco area for over 50 years specializing in business, banking, finance, and nonprofits. He was selected as the 42nd President of The Explorers Club in 2012, specializing in Tibet, China, and sacred mountains. He was the first Westerner to circumambulate sacred Mt. Kailas after Tibet opened to foreigners, and bicycled the entire Silk Road in stages (2001-2008).

name: North, D. Warner
title: Principal Scientist / Retired Consulting Professor
ngos: San Francisco Classical Voice (SFCV) - Board of Directors
notes: D. Warner North is a decision and risk analyst and Principal Scientist of NorthWorks, a consulting firm in San Francisco, CA. He served as Consulting Professor in the Department of Management Science and Engineering at Stanford University until 2009. He holds a BS in Physics from Yale (1962) and a PhD in Operations Research from Stanford (1970). He received the Ramsey Medal from the Decision Analysis Society (1997) and the Outstanding Risk Practitioner Award from the Society for Risk Analysis (1999). He has contributed to major National Research Council reports on risk assessment and risk communication.

name: Ogburn, Matthew M.
employer: Law Offices of Matthew M. Ogburn / formerly Helm Financial Corporation
title: Attorney / formerly Senior Officer and Director
notes: Matthew M. Ogburn is a California attorney (bar #148658) in San Francisco specializing in business and equipment leasing law. He was formerly a senior officer and Board member of Helm Financial Corporation, an equipment lessor of railroad rolling stock based in San Francisco, where he managed credit facilities exceeding $400 million. Helm Financial was acquired by First Union Rail Corporation (Wells Fargo) in April 2014.

name: Owens, Bill USN (Ret.)
employer: Various boards / Retired military and private sector
title: Retired Admiral, U.S. Navy; Former Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
ngos: Stimson Center; EastWest Institute; American Security Project
notes: Admiral William Arthur Owens USN (Ret.) (born May 8, 1940) served as Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff (1994-1996), the second-highest military position in the U.S., appointed by President Clinton. He is a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy (1962) and a Rhodes Scholar (Oxford, PPE). Post-retirement, he was President/COO/Vice Chairman of SAIC (1996-1998), CEO of Nortel Networks (2004-2005), and non-executive Chairman of CenturyLink (2009+). He has served on over 20 public company boards including Daimler, British American Tobacco, Telstra, Nortel Networks, and Polycom.

name: Prusiner, Stanley B.
title: Nobel Laureate; Professor and Director, Institute for Neurodegenerative Diseases
ngos: BrightFocus Foundation (board member); UsAgainstAlzheimer's (advisory); Priavoid (Supervisory Board, 2020)
notes: Stanley B. Prusiner, MD (born May 28, 1942) is a UCSF professor and Director of the Institute for Neurodegenerative Diseases (since 1999). He received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1997 for discovering prions - an unprecedented class of proteinaceous infectious pathogens responsible for scrapie, bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans. He received his BA in Chemistry (1964) and MD (1968) from the University of Pennsylvania. He joined UCSF in 1974. He also chairs the Scientific Advisory Board of Alzheon and joined the supervisory board of Priavoid (2020).

(founded 1999, a business intelligence software company). He previously spent 14 years as Vice President/Director at Mercer Management Consulting. He has over 25 years of supply chain management and logistics experience, including 14+ years at Menlo Logistics and a period at cybersecurity firm FireEye. He holds an MBA in Organization Development and a BA in Political Science from the University of Southern California. He is associated with an address in Portola Valley, CA.

name: Tuttle, Crawford

notes: Crawford Tuttle has a background in California state government and environmental policy. He served as Deputy Secretary for Environmental Protection at the California Environmental Protection Agency (1996-1999), Washington Representative at the State of California Governor's Washington DC Office (1994-1996), and Policy and Budget Examiner at the Office of Management and Budget (1991-1994). He holds an MA from Georgetown University. He later worked at Emcot Forests, the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire), and the California Natural Resources Agency before moving to Fisher Investments as a Program Manager.

name: Bratton, Douglas K.

notes: Douglas K. Bratton founded Crestline Investors in 1997, growing it into a $19 billion credit alternative asset manager. Previously spent six years with Taylor & Company associated with members of the Bass family; holds BS from NC State (1981) and MBA with Honors from Duke University (1984).

notes: 7th president of Northeastern University since 2006. Lebanese-born American linguist with PhD from MIT. name: Boggan, James E.

notes: Neurosurgeon born in Chicago in 1949. Graduated from University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine in 1976. Completed neurosurgical residency at UCSF in 1982. Joined UC Davis faculty in 1985; promoted to Professor in 1993. Appointed Julian R. Youmans Professor and Endowed Chair in Neurological Surgery in 2013. Recognized in Castle Connolly's America's Top Doctors.

name: Caplan, Thomas M.
title: Novelist
ngos: PEN/Faulkner Foundation (founder, former chairman, board member emeritus)
notes: Novelist and longtime close friend of President Bill Clinton; the two met as Georgetown freshmen in 1964. Georgetown School of Foreign Service graduate; MBA from Harvard. Author of four novels: The Spy Who Jumped Off the Screen, Line of Chance, Parallelogram, and Grace and Favor. Son of Marvin Caplan, the Baltimore jeweler to the Kennedy family. Lives on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

name: Chang, James

ngos: ReSurge International (Consulting Medical Officer)
notes: Hand and upper extremity surgeon. BA/BS from Stanford in Biology and Economics; MD from Yale (Alpha Omega Alpha, Cum Laude). Served as Division Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Stanford from 2006 until recently stepping down after over 20 years. Elected to the American Surgical Association in 2010. Past president of the American Society for Surgery of the Hand (2017-18).

name: DeGrado, William F.

notes: Pioneer of de novo protein design who coined the term. Elected to National Academy of Sciences (1999), American Academy of Arts and Sciences (1998), and National Academy of Inventors (2014). Career began at DuPont (1981-1996), then University of Pennsylvania (1996-2011), then UCSF. Scientific co-founder of Pliant Therapeutics and founder of PolyMedix. Best known for his Investment Theory of Party Competition, detailed in his 1995 book Golden Rule. Contributing editor at The Nation. Member of editorial board of the International Journal of Political Economy. Research focuses on money in politics and campaign finance.

Completed neurology residency at University of Washington and nuclear medicine residency at UCLA. Joined UCSB faculty in 2006. Co-Director at the Institute for Collaborative Biotechnologies (DoD-funded). Author of Physical Intelligence (2020). Over 230 peer-reviewed publications.

Donated $600,000 to Equality Utah, an LGBTQ rights organization. Lives in Newbury Park, California.

Lives in Tiburon, California.

Reporter for the American Law Institute's Federal Judicial Code Revision Project (1995-2004). Served as Chair of the UC Academic Council and faculty representative to the Regents (2006-07). Recipient of the 2012 Oliver Johnson Award for Distinguished Service to the UC Academic Senate.

Turing Award for developing RISC architecture. Coined the term RISC and led the Berkeley RISC project; also led research on RAID storage. ACM President 2004-2006. Fellow of ACM, IEEE, and AAAS. U.S. Special Envoy for Northern Ireland with Ambassador rank (2003-2007). Chief negotiator at Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO, 1995-1999). 27th President of Washington College (2010-2014). 8th President and CEO of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation (2014-2019). National Security Adviser to Mitt Romney's 2008 and 2012 presidential campaigns. Author of Negotiating with Evil (2010) and Bridled Ambition (1995).
